subject: Re: Oh Bruce...
author: psi_research
full_text:
I believe it was a 13 tone generator. If I remember, one of the early
engineers behind the Moog synthesizer helped development of the Spiricom.

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "lil_piggsy" <piggsy@...> wrote:
>
> 
> I forgot how many discrete tones were used in the Spiricom. IIRC, the
> theory of operation was all of the tones and harmonics were combined
> to create voices. The recorded output was somewhat hard for me to
> understand due to all of those tones. Now what if the discrete tones
> could somehow be filtered out of the output, allowing only processed
> voice to pass through? I'm sure the circuitry would be very
> complicated. This is probably just the Ny-Quil talking though.
> Electronic engineering is beyond the scope of my knowledge.
> 
> Good Night!
> 
> 
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "psi_research" <vilhellm@> wrote:
> >
> > That would be interesting, a hardware version of evp maker that would
> > sample the voice of a person speaking into a mic onto a memory chip.
> > Then slice,scramble, and play back that persons voice. It would be an
> > alternative to a tuner and to the RNG concept, which is also good. The
> > RNG idea Frank S proposed reminds me of Spiricom if you use tone
> > generators that mimic the human voice. 
> > -Bill
> >
